page.title: 13Plant and Bird Life
page.content: The most significant feature of Biological interest in the area is the steep sided valley of the river Blyth. The river banks are heavily wooded with some open spaces on the north bank where there is easy public access, at Hartford Hall (Trees) present include: Beech, Oak, Elm, Ash, Sycamore, Horse Chestnut, Svot's Pine, Rowan & Elder. "I took a walk down a piece of woodland path about lkm long, and tallied off the trees within 5m of the path: Beech -l5, Hawthorn -l3, Ash -ll, Oak -9, Pine - 6" The varied habitats attract a wide range of (birds). Some are attracted by the river itself, e.g. Moorhen, Dipper, Kingfisher, and Heron, others by the woodland scrub & open spaces along its banks, eg Sparrow Hawk, Kestrel, Wren, Wood Pigeon, Chaffinch & Blue Tits.
